content:
The "Science and Technology Innovation Act of 2008" includes reauthorization of programs, federal innovation investments, utilization support, and outreach and technical assistance. It extends SBIR and STTR programs, increases caps, adjusts award levels, and supports program evaluation and technology utilization through agency databases. Title V of the "Science and Technology Innovation Act of 2008" includes provisions for conforming amendments, a National Research Council study, and implementation details. The reauthorization of SBIR and STTR programs extends the programs to 2010, with an increase in the SBIR cap. Title II of the "Science and Technology Innovation Act of 2008" amends the Small Business Act to increase the SBIR and STTR caps for fiscal years 2009 and beyond. SEC. 202 of the "Science and Technology Innovation Act of 2008" increases the STTR cap to 0.6 percent for fiscal year 2009 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to increase SBIR and STTR funding limits. SBIR limits are raised from $100,000 to $300,000 and from $750,000 to $2,200,000. STTR limits are also increased to the same amounts. Additionally, annual adjustments will now be mandatory to reflect economic changes and program considerations. The Small Business Act is amended to increase SBIR and STTR funding limits, with mandatory annual adjustments to reflect economic changes and program considerations. Additionally, there is a limitation on the size of awards issued under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Small Business Act is amended to increase SBIR and STTR funding limits, with mandatory annual adjustments to reflect economic changes and program considerations. There is also a limitation on the size of awards issued under the SBIR and STTR programs. Small businesses may receive awards for subsequent phases from different Federal agencies if the topics align, and they can apply directly for a Phase II award without completing a Phase I if project feasibility was achieved without federal funding. The Small Business Act is amended to increase SBIR and STTR funding limits, with mandatory annual adjustments. Small businesses can apply for Phase II awards without completing Phase I if they can demonstrate accomplishment without federal funding. Agencies may waive work requirements for SBIR or STTR awards if consistent with program objectives. SEC. 204. MAJORITY EQUITY INVESTMENT IN SBIR AND STTR FIRMS. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow small businesses to be majority owned by multiple equity providers, with no single provider owning more than 49 percent. Equity providers are defined as venture capital operating companies. The Small Business Act is amended to allow small businesses to be majority owned by multiple equity providers, with no single provider owning more than 49 percent. Equity providers are venture capital operating companies, registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940, or investment companies not registered under the Act if beneficially owned by less than 100 persons. SEC. 301. AGENCY DATABASES TO SUPPORT PROGRAM EVALUATION. Section 9(k) of the Small Business Act is amended to include new requirements for information on the ownership structure of award recipients. Federal agencies are required to update information in their databases before making payments to small business concerns. The Small Business Act now requires small business concerns to provide all necessary information for awards received, including ownership structure details. Small business concerns can apportion sales or investment information for multiple awards. Annual updates are required for award recipients under this section. Small business concerns receiving awards must update information in databases at the end of the award period. Recipients not described in clause (iii) are requested to voluntarily update information annually for 5 years. Small business concerns applying for subsequent awards must update information annually for 5 years. Each Federal agency with an SBIR or STTR program must maintain a database for program evaluation purposes, accessible to other agencies. SEC. 302. AGENCY DATABASES TO SUPPORT TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION. Section 9(k) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Federal agencies with SBIR or STTR programs to create and maintain technology utilization databases. These databases will contain data from award recipients to help attract customers, investors, and business partners. Participation is voluntary, except for award recipients who are required to participate. Award recipients who received supplemental payments from SBIR and STTR program funds above their initial Phase II award are required to participate in technology utilization databases. SEC. 303. INTERAGENCY POLICY COMMITTEE. The Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee, chaired by the Directors of the Office of Science and Technology Policy and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, will review issues related to improving program effectiveness and efficiency, including databases and award sizes. The Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee will review award sizes and criteria flexibility, commercialization assistance best practices, and propose new initiatives to address funding gaps. Reports will be transmitted to relevant committees within a year of the Act's enactment. The Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee will submit reports on its review and recommendations within specific timeframes after the enactment of the Act. TITLE IV--OUTREACH AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

SEC. 401. USE OF PROGRAM FUNDS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS.

Amends the Small Business Act to limit administrative costs to no more than 3.0 percent.

SEC. 402. SBIR DISCRETIONARY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. Section 9(q) of the Small Business Act is amended to include implementing manufacturing processes and production strategies for utilization. Assistance providers may select a vendor to assist small business concerns. Section 9(q) of the Small Business Act is amended to include implementing manufacturing processes and production strategies for utilization. Assistance providers may select a vendor to assist small business concerns in meeting specified goals for up to 3 years through a competitive selection process based on merit. Agencies may also collaborate with other Federal agencies for technical extension or assistance programs. Additionally, adjustments are made to funding amounts in paragraph (3). The Small Business Act is amended to allow SBIR award recipients to purchase services up to $8,000 per year per award. SEC. 501: The Small Business Administration must update SBIR and STTR Policy Directives to align with this Act within 180 days of enactment.

SEC. 502: Amendments are made to the Small Business Reauthorization Act of 2000 regarding the National Research Council SBIR study.
